title: Mid-Rectal Cancer Requiring Low Anterior Resection
setup_script: A 60-year-old man presents with rectal bleeding and change in stool caliber. Colonoscopy reveals a mid-rectal mass 8 cm from the anal verge. Biopsy confirms adenocarcinoma. MRI shows T3N0 tumor without mesorectal fascia involvement.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Take history of bleeding, bowel habits, weight loss, and risk factors; perform digital rectal exam assessing sphincter tone and tumor mobility.
Order staging studies: pelvic MRI, endorectal ultrasound, CT chest/abdomen/pelvis, CEA level.
Discuss treatment sequencing: neoadjuvant chemoradiation for T3 tumors to downstage and improve margin status.
Refer to multidisciplinary tumor board; coordinate with medical and radiation oncology for neoadjuvant therapy.
Monitor patient during chemoradiation; manage side effects and assess tumor response with repeat MRI.
Plan for low anterior resection with total mesorectal excision (TME) 6-8 weeks after completion of radiation.
Obtain informed consent discussing risks: anastomotic leak, need for temporary diverting ileostomy, sexual/urinary dysfunction.
Perform laparoscopic or robotic low anterior resection with TME; achieve negative circumferential and distal margins; create diverting ileostomy.
Postoperative care: monitor hemodynamics, stoma, and pelvic drains; start enhanced recovery pathway.
Review pathology for tumor regression grade, lymph nodes, and margins; determine need for adjuvant chemotherapy.
Manage stoma and plan for reversal after completion of adjuvant therapy and confirmation of anastomotic integrity.
Arrange surveillance with colonoscopy, CEA every 3-6 months, and periodic imaging for recurrence.

critical_decision_points: Appropriate staging and multidisciplinary management of rectal cancer.
Indication for neoadjuvant chemoradiation in T3 lesions.
Technical execution of total mesorectal excision and creation of diverting ileostomy.
Postoperative monitoring and timely stoma reversal.
